intro: Sida parviflora, commonly known as smallflower mallow, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the Americas. It typically grows to a height of 30 to 60 centimeters and features alternate, ovate to lanceolate leaves with hairy surfaces. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers that are clustered in loose inflorescences. Its fibrous roots and stems are often used in traditional medicine for their purported healing properties. Sida parviflora thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands, marshes, and along stream banks.
